title: The Evidence Towards Impact: The Maricopa Millions OER Project

author: Paul Golisch, Paradise Valley Community College
Lisa Young, Scottsdale Community College

segmentation: My name is Lisa Young and I am an instructional design educational technology faculty member at the Maricopa Community Colleges.
This is Paul Girlish and he is our Chief Information Officer as well as a math instructor and we want to tell you a little bit about our own.
We are project.
First, let me tell you a little bit about the Maricopa Community colleges.
We are arguably the largest Community College in the nation of the United States of America.
We are located in Arizona and our 10 colleges offer 37 associate degrees over 10,000 courses.
We have nearly 10,000 employees and we have more than 250,000 students in our district.
We have a bit of a problem in that our tuition is fairly inexpensive, so students aren't paying a great amount of money for college.
However, they are paying over 1/4 of their educational expenses in textbooks.
And when you think about where textbook money goes when we think about who is making the money in regard to textbooks in America, the textbook dollar is quaint distributed.
But most of the money goes to the publishers.
The book stores an overhead, while only 11.6% goes to the author.
And so a lot of students think, oh, the textbook authors are making a lot of money on these published textbooks.
But that isn't the case.

Another argument that we often hear is that our open textbooks aren't of a high quality, but we all here know that that isn't the case, that there are wonderful open educational resources for our students, and so there are a number of programs like Openstax College which are peer reviewed, open educational resource materials that have textbooks that have iPad applications that have a number of different great resources, homework systems, test banks.
All put together that provide us our students with the same materials they would get from a publisher, but for free or very low cost.
And so we wanted to just set the National open educational resources scene for you in the United States.

What you see is the green states are members of the Community College Consortium for Open Educational Resources, part of the OEC and the blue the Stars here are major ovr projects in the United States.
Now what's really exciting about what's happening in regard to community colleges and universities in the United States are these blue colors.
As what's happening there is we have a number of politicians of legislators that are working to John something called the Affordable Textbook Act.
An affordable textbook act.
If it passes, we'll do a number of things looking at grant programs to support or we are making sure that any materials that are created using public funds could have a Creative Commons license.
We're looking at reporting on program effectiveness in using open and basically reporting regularly on the price of textbooks and these trends.
Now this is huge for the United States.
This is a really big deal, and so we have four legislators who are working on promoting this.
An getting more and more involvement across the United States, and we hope we really hope that this comes to fruition.
That we that are affordable textbook care Affordable Textbook Act.

We have an Affordable Care Act also that the Affordable Textbook Act will pass and that will be able to eliminate so much of those overhead costs for our students and provide those really rich materials for them.
And so I'm going to pass this on to Paul for just a little while, and what I'm going to talk about is how ojars are being used here in Maricopa Community colleges.
Lisa said that's a 10 college district in Phoenix, AZ.
And how it started is at some of the colleges and especially at Scotts Dale Community College.
That's why I've got that larger.
And we've got one of our pioneers here in the audience.
Donna Gaudet is over there.
She just presented on Moocs earlier today and some of the great work that they've done at Scotts Dale.

But at the same time over at Phoenix College we have a few people using open educational resources and it started with someone named James Souza, Anna couple other colleagues, and they're doing a lot of great work.
I'll talk about later.
Then at my college we had a little bit smaller.
Start to open educational resources again.
Were ten call.
Just we want to talk about how we had these pockets of innovation going on and how it started as grassroots.
And then how we are trying to scale it up.
So as you can see, we had a lot of things going on in math, but we did have a few other areas doing a few things.
So here's an example of what we were doing in math, and this is hosted over at Scotts Dale Community College.

It is hosted on something called My Open math that actually has a few different names, but what you could use and you could all go to this if you want to set up your own account, just go to myopenmath.com and you can set up an account.
It's really a whole learning management system.
It has homework exercises.
You could set up quizzes, tests, there's videos you can put in there.
Discussion boards, grade books.
It's a lot of great material.
Offer free David Lipman over in Pierce College in the state of Washington.
Put that all together.
So some of the impact that's going on just with those pockets of innovation.
I surveyed some my students here and I know it's a little bit a lot of information on here, but basically I asked them what do you think about the videos in the free textbook and the free homework.
And overwhelmingly they said it was somewhat helpful or very helpful.
Of course, there's some that don't use the textbook, there's some just prefer to use the videos.
Then I ask them what do you think about taking your next class?
Would this be very important to have a free textbook?
And I just heard from another instructor that one of her students is not going to be taking math in the summer because the free textbooks not ready till the fall.
So she's going to wait until that free textbook is available.
So I think that is very important for some of the students.
Then I also asked them just for some feedback on the class and somebody here said it was great not having to pay for the text.
It allowed me to pay my water bill so I could shower which was great and all the other students really appreciated that.
And also to clean their sweet potatoes in the sink, which I guess is very important to her.

Here's a survey that Donna and her colleagues over at Scotts Dale Community College did on the on how the open materials supported the work they did outside of class and whether they would recommend them to their classmates.
Such an important thing as we see in trip adviser and YouTube and all these things is what are your peers saying?
And so the peers here overwhelmingly said that yes, these were great materials only a few said maybe I wouldn't recommend that for my colleagues couple other things, I want to point up.

But he said it was during spring break, so the views were down a little bit.
One thing that I thought was particularly interesting, especially for this conference is take a look at viewing across the world all the different views just in one month.

All these different views and I attended on Tuesday the Pre Conference workshop about transcription and translation an I think if we can get these translated into Spanish and some others, then I think we'll see some even more countries.
And now I'll hand it back over to Lisa and see how we're going to scale the usage of this to know something.
I just want to share with you is in America because students have to pay so much for their textbooks.
Many students don't buy the textbook.
In fact, about 50% of the students don't buy the textbook.
70% of them don't have the textbook on the first day.
50% never buy the textbook.
And so as an instructor, as a faculty member, I expect my students to do the reading and come to class prepared.
But they're not coming to class because of the exorbitant price.
And what's interesting is that Scotts Dale Community College.
Since they put their open workbook made that available, it's about $20 and the students do buy it in the bookstore.
The use rate by students, the students purchasing the book has gone up to 83% and students can also print it on their own.
So we're getting a huge infiltration of use of the textbook by going open.
So we're very large institution.
I already mentioned 10 colleges, 250,000 students, and we want to make a difference for our students.

And so we want to save them money and our leaders want us to save our students money and so a little over Europe ago, about 15 months ago, our one of our leaders of the Maricopa Community College District, our Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost.
Put together a small team of faculty and said I want you to do some research on this.
Oh ER.

And so we got together and we put together a proposal and we called it the Maricopa Millions project and we started with let's get the best people we can together and put together a steering team and we put a call out and of course we have our executive sponsor who is our Executive Vice Chancellor, Provost and then we had two college presidents.
Volunteer to be on our team.
We also have 9 faculty on the team, vice presidents and Deans of colleges.
We have library faculty, instructional designers, instructional technologists, an IT professionals, all meeting together twice a month to move our initiative forward.
So we got everyone involved and we developed a strategic plan and sometimes people are like Oh no strategic plan.
But we put this plan together and we work that plan and we we revisit it regularly.
And we want to make sure that we're going to have a big impact on our students.
We also put together a website and we've been flashing it throughout the presentation and you'll have a chance to jot it down several more times.
